wikipedia_page.main: John Beddoe FRS FRAI (21 September 1826 – 19 July 1911) was one of the most prominent English ethnologists in Victorian Britain.

response: Among the other founders were James Cowles Prichard,RAI page: Prichard centenary. John Beddoe and John Brown. Apart from Hodgkin, King and Dieffenbach, the other significant common member with the APS was William Aldam, another Quaker.Rainger, p. 711. The Society had Corresponding Members, who counted as Fellows;RAI page: Local Correspondents. they later included Hermann Welcker.Hermann Welcker and J. B. D., On the Skull of Dante, Anthropological Review , Vol. 5, No. 16 (Jan., 1867), pp. 56–71. Published by: Royal Anthropological Institute of Great Britain and Ireland. . . In the early days the Society had rooms at 27 Sackville Street, which were rented through King to the Westminster Medical Society.D. Zuck, The Westminster Medical Society 1809–1850, The History of Anaesthesia Society Proceedings vol. 42 (2010), pp. 9–25; ; PDF, at p. 16.
*John Beddoe, ethnologist, was born in Bewdley in 1826.
The Victorian ethnologist John Beddoe noted the similarity between the name Tytila and that of Totila, an Ostrogoth king.Beddoe, The Races of Britain, p. 42.
